elements.content: The fluorescence of uranyl originated from electronic transitions (S11–S00 and S10–S0v, v = 0–4) of the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) process is an intrinsic property of many uranyl coordination compounds. However, light-induced regulation on fluorescence features of uranyl hybrid materials through photoactive functional groups is less investigated. In this work, the photoactive vinyl group-containing ligands, (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-4-yl)­acrylate and (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-3-yl)­acrylate, have been used in the construction of uranyl coordination polymers in the presence of 1,10-phenanthroline (phen). Five compounds (UO2)3(μ3-O)­(μ2-OH)2(L1 )2(phen)2(1), (UO2)3(μ3-O)­(μ2-OH)3(L1 )­(phen)2 (2), (UO2)3(μ3-O)­(μ2-OH)3(L2 )­(phen)2 (3), [(UO2)2(μ2-OH)2(L2 )2(phen)2]·2H2O (4), and (UO2)­Zn­(SO4)­(phen)­(H2O)­(OH)2(5) were obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1–4 are polynuclear uranyl structures with abundant π–π interactions and hydrogen bonds contributed to the 3D crystal packing of them. As model compounds, 1 and 3 are selected for exploring photoresponsive behaviors. The emission intensities of these two compounds are found to decrease gradually over the exposure time of UV irradiation. X-ray single crystal structural analysis suggests that the fluorescence attenuation can be explained by the slight rotation of pyridinyl groups around the carbon–carbon double bond during UV irradiation, which is accompanied by the change of weak interactions, i.e., π–π interactions and hydrogen bonds in strength and density. This feature of light-induced fluorescence attenuation may enable these two compounds to act as potential photoresponsive sensor materials.

elements.content: Uranyl complexes incorporating photoactive vinylpyridine moieties display interesting light-induced fluorescence attenuation, which might be attributed to the slight rotation of pyridinyl group around the carbon−carbon double bond, leading to the increased degree of the nonradiative relaxation of excited states and final fluorescence attenuation of the irradiated compounds.

elements.content: Over the past decades, research on coordination polymers (CPs) has aroused intense interest from chemists and material scientists for their various molecular architectures and potential applications in various fields such as ion exchange, magnetism, nonlinear optics, luminescence sensors, gas storage, and separation. Compared with massive efforts devoted to transition and lanthanide metals, CPs based on actinide elements are still less developed. The study of actinide-based CPs can give much information on the intriguing 5f bonding features, which is beneficial to the strategy for nuclear waste management, and is also helpful for exploring physicochemical properties of actinide hybrid materials and promoting their potential utilization. As one of the most important actinide elements in the nuclear fuel cycle and a natural element with the highest atomic number, uranium-related study dominates the actinide-based coordination compounds. The main oxidation state of uranium in nature is U­(VI) in the form of uranyl cation UO2 2+, which possesses a special linear structure with two axial oxygen atoms. Generally, the exotic ligands coordinate with uranium center only through additional coordination sites around its equatorial plane, leading to the formation of common coordination spheres of uranyl in tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramidal geometries as seen in a large library of uranyl-organic CPs reported previously.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decades, research on coordination polymers (CPs) has aroused intense interest from chemists and material scientists for their various molecular architectures and potential applications in various fields such as ion exchange, magnetism, nonlinear optics, luminescence sensors, gas storage, and separation. Compared with massive efforts devoted to transition and lanthanide metals, CPs based on actinide elements are still less developed. The study of actinide-based CPs can give much information on the intriguing 5f bonding features, which is beneficial to the strategy for nuclear waste management, and is also helpful for exploring physicochemical properties of actinide hybrid materials and promoting their potential utilization. As one of the most important actinide elements in the nuclear fuel cycle and a natural element with the highest atomic number, uranium-related study dominates the actinide-based coordination compounds. The main oxidation state of uranium in nature is U(VI) in the form of uranyl cation UO2 2+, which possesses a special linear structure with two axial oxygen atoms. Generally, the exotic ligands coordinate with uranium center only through additional coordination sites around its equatorial plane, leading to the formation of common coordination spheres of uranyl in tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramidal geometries as seen in a large library of uranyl-organic CPs reported previously.

elements.content: The careful selection of organic ligands serves as a key step for the preparation of new uranyl-organic CPs. In general, multidentate flexible or rigid ligands with increased numbers of coordination groups and/or increased dimensionality of molecular skeletons are good candidates for constructing CPs with fascinating topologies or high porosity. The construction of new functional uranyl coordination compounds rely mainly on those modified with functional groups or active sites, which are exemplified by previous studies focusing on potential functionality of uranyl coordination compounds as demonstrated above, such as dynamic pseudorotaxane motif or photo/electro-active viologen groups. Most research on uranium coordination compounds mainly focused on their abundant topologies as well as high porosity, which partly follow the methodology from MOF chemistry. Recently, inspired by the potential application of these functional uranyl coordination compounds, research work on this catalogue of uranyl hybrid materials has been emerging and developing rapidly. For example, the latest work by Wang et al. based on uranyl-oxalate and uranyl-BCPBA (BCPBA: 3,5-bis (4′-carboxylphenoxy) benzoic acid) demonstrates the potential application of uranyl coordination compounds in the field of radiation detection and aggregation-induced emission (AIE). Mechanically interlocked motifs (such as (pseudoro)­rotaxane and catenane) with potential molecular dynamics have been incorporated into the frameworks of uranyl-organic coordination polymers by our group. Meanwhile, we also successfully prepared several photochromic uranyl coordination compounds from viologen-bearing ligands. These initial trials prove functional uranyl-organic coordination compounds to be promising as potential hybrid materials in many fields, and thus propel further exploration for new functional uranyl coordination compounds.

elements.content: As a well-known photoactive unit, vinyl group can undergo the characteristic cis–trans photoisomerization reaction, [2 + 2] photocycloaddition, or other photoinduced reactions or structural variation after light exposure, and may lead to the changes of parent compounds in physicochemical properties such as photochromic phenomenon, fluorescence emission, or UV–vis absorption. Herein, we intend to introduce a photoactive vinyl group to functionalize uranyl-organic coordination compounds and regulate their photochemical behavior. Therefore, to prepare photoactive uranyl compounds and explore their photoresponsive capability, we select (E)-3-(pyridin-4-yl)­acrylic acid (HL1 ) and (E)-3-(pyridin-3-yl)­acrylic acid (HL2 ) () as a combination of vinyl group and pyridine-containing isonicotinic or nicotinic acid, both of which are good ligands for uranyl employed in our previous work. It can be expected that the implantation of the vinylpyridine (VP) group into the backbones or side chains of uranyl coordination compounds will endow them with new photoactive features and photoresponsible behaviors.

It can be expected that the implantation of the vinylpyridine (VP) group into the backbones or side chains of uranyl coordination compounds will endow them with new photoactive features and photoresponsible behaviors.

elements.content: In this work, five new uranyl coordination compounds with VP-functionalized L1 or L2 linker and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) auxiliary ligand, 1–5, were hydrothermally synthesized from uranyl and methyl ester of HL1 or HL2 , i.e., (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-4-yl)­acrylate (L1 -OMe) and (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-3-yl)­acrylate (L2 -OMe). Especially, 1 and 3 were selected as representative samples to investigate their photoactive properties. Both compounds exhibit obvious photoresponse effect, and their fluorescence intensity would be reduced with increasing exposure time, X-ray single crystal structural analysis reveals that the mechanism for light-induced fluorescence attenuation may be caused by the slight rotation of pyridinyl around the carbon–carbon double bond, which might lead to the increased degree of the nonradiative relaxation of excited states and fluorescence attenuation of the irradiated compounds (1-ir and 3-ir). Moreover, infrared (IR) spectra, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and luminescence properties of typical compounds were also studied. In addition, factors controlling the synthesis and structural diversity were also discussed, such as the solution pH values, auxiliary ligands, or competing agent, as well as of the position of the pyridinyl nitrogen atom.

elements.content: Caution! Because of the radioactive and chemically toxic nature of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, precautions with suitable care and protection are supposed to be followed. L1 -OMe and L2 -OMe were prepared by a modified literature method. All the chemical reagents were commercially supplied and used without further purification. UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (12.55g, 0.025 mol) was dissolved in deionized water (50 mL) to give a stock solution of uranyl nitrate (0.50 M).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Caution! Because of the radioactive and chemically toxic nature of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O, precautions with suitable care and protection are supposed to be followed. L1 -OMe and L2 -OMe were prepared by a modified literature method. All the chemical reagents were commercially supplied and used without further purification. UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (12.55g, 0.025 mol) was dissolved in deionized water (50 mL) to give a stock solution of uranyl nitrate (0.50 M).

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction measurements (PXRD) were obtained with a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) in the range of 5–50° (step size: 0.02°). Elemental analyses were performed with a vario EL Elemental Analyzer (Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded from a TA Q500 analyzer over the temperature range of 25–800 °C in air atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The Fourier transform infrared (IR) spectra were performed on KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: All of the uranyl compounds in this work were hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves. The corresponding synthetic conditions are recorded as followed.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

All of the uranyl compounds in this work were hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure using 15 mL Teflon-lined Parr-type autoclaves. The corresponding synthetic conditions are recorded as followed.

elements.content: A mixture of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 100 μL), L1 -OMe (16.3 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (18.1 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (1 M, 120 μL), and ultrapure water (2.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL stainless steel bomb. The bomb was sealed, heated to 150 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. Bright-yellow prismatic crystals of 1, accompanied by a small amount of yellow floc, were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ethanol and ultrapure water, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 6.4 mg, 10.7% based on uranium. Elemental analysis calculated for C40H28N6O13U3, C, 31.67; H, 1.99; N, 5.54. Found: C, 33.80; H, 2.24; N, 5.81% (the deviation beyond the ±0.4% range is mainly originated from a small amount of impurity including reactants and/or byproducts generating during the hydrothermal reaction between multiple components; according to the experimental analysis result, the sample purity for compound 1 is still as high as ∼98%, which is also evidenced by the high similarity of PXRD patterns between experimental data and simulated data as shown in SI).

elements.content: A 100 mL jacketed quartz beaker cooled by circulation water was used as a container with samples put in it and a 365 nm UV lamp (100 W) was mounted right above the container. After irradiation for 1, 4, and 7 h, fluorescence spectra of irradiated samples were recorded immediately. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements and X-ray single crystal structural determination of the irradiated compounds after 7 h (namely as 1-ir and 3-ir) were also conducted. Subsequently, the samples of 1-ir and 3-ir were heated at 180 °C for 12 h, and then cooled to ambient temperature to afford compounds of 1-ir-heat and 3-ir-heat, which were also characterized by fluorescence spectrum, powder X-ray diffraction measurements, and X-ray single crystal structural determination.
elements.clean_text:
Light-Induced Experiments

A 100 mL jacketed quartz beaker cooled by circulation water was used as a container with samples put in it and a 365 nm UV lamp (100 W) was mounted right above the container. After irradiation for 1, 4, and 7 h, fluorescence spectra of irradiated samples were recorded immediately. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements and X-ray single crystal structural determination of the irradiated compounds after 7 h (namely as 1-ir and 3-ir) were also conducted. Subsequently, the samples of 1-ir and 3-ir were heated at 180 °C for 12 h, and then cooled to ambient temperature to afford compounds of 1-ir-heat and 3-ir-heat, which were also characterized by fluorescence spectrum, powder X-ray diffraction measurements, and X-ray single crystal structural determination.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data of all compounds were collected on a Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray CMOS diffractometer with a Mo Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.71073 Å) or a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54184 Å) at room temperature. All the crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-97, and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions, and all hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. The crystal data of all these five compounds are given in . Crystallographic data for the structures in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC-1865351 (1), CCDC-1865345 (1-ir), CCDC-1865347 (1-ir-heat), CCDC-1865348 (2), CCDC-1865346 (3), CCDC-1865344 (3-ir), CCDC-1865350 (3-ir-heat), CCDC-1865352 (4), and CCDC-1865349 (5).

X-ray Single Crystal Structure Determination

X-ray diffraction data of all compounds were collected on a Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray CMOS diffractometer with a Mo Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.71073 Å) or a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54184 Å) at room temperature. All the crystal structures were solved by means of direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-97, and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed at calculated positions, and all hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. The crystal data of all these five compounds are given in . Crystallographic data for the structures in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC-1865351 (1), CCDC-1865345 (1-ir), CCDC-1865347 (1-ir-heat), CCDC-1865348 (2), CCDC-1865346 (3), CCDC-1865344 (3-ir), CCDC-1865350 (3-ir-heat), CCDC-1865352 (4), and CCDC-1865349 (5).

Compound 1 crystallizes with the appearance of snowflake-like prismatic crystals in the triclinic space group P1̅ (Figure S1), and contains three kinds of components, uranyl units, L1 linkers, and phen molecules in its asymmetric unit (Figure S2). Two different uranyl moieties of tetra-nuclear and dimeric uranyl motifs, which are linked by a L1 linker to form a one-dimensional (1D) chain, are found in 1 (a,b). In terms of dimeric uranyl polyhedral, it is formed by two crystallographically equivalent uranyl center U1, sharing one equatorial edge with each other through two O atoms with U–O bond lengths of 2.259(3) and 2.361(3) Å (Table S1). Besides, two N atoms from a phen molecule and an end η1-carboxyl O atom (O8) of L1 linker occupy the residual coordination sites of the equatorial plane with U–O bond length of 2.347(9) Å, and U–N bond lengths of 2.608(4) and 2.605(4) Å, respectively (c). The other N-donor end of the bridging L1 linker is coordinated with the tetra-nuclear motif (U2–N3, 2.648(3) Å). Besides, another two L1 linkers also coordinate to the tetra-nuclear motif (d) by the carboxyl group in a bidentate bridging mode (U2–O10, 2.433(3) Å; U3–O11, 2.358(3) Å), leaving the other pyridine-containing end uncoordinated and dangled. Moreover, phen molecules chelate to the tetra-nuclear uranyl in a way similar to that in dimeric uranyl (U3–N4, 2.691(4) Å; U3–N5, 2.679(3) Å). It is interesting to find that, all the dangled L1 linkers and phen molecules are orderly aligned as branch motifs on both sides along the 1D chain formed containing dimeric and tetrameric uranyl clusters. These widespread conjugated groups of dangled L1 linkers and phen molecules promote the formation of a 3D supramolecular architecture via π–π interactions (e and Figure S3). Specifically, the π–π interaction arises mainly from the stacking of side-on phen moieties binding to tetra-nuclear uranyl entities with a face-to-face distance (Cg(1)–Cg(2)) of 3.673(0) Å (f and ), which makes different components in 1 to hold together tightly. Certainly, besides π–π interactions, widespread C–H···O­(axial) or C–H···N­(prydinyl) also contribute to the crystal lattice stacking in 3D space (Figure S4 and Table S2).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

Compound 1 crystallizes with the appearance of snowflake-like prismatic crystals in the triclinic space group P1̅ (Figure S1), and contains three kinds of components, uranyl units, L1  linkers, and phen molecules in its asymmetric unit (Figure S2). Two different uranyl moieties of tetra-nuclear and dimeric uranyl motifs, which are linked by a L1  linker to form a one-dimensional (1D) chain, are found in 1 (a,b). In terms of dimeric uranyl polyhedral, it is formed by two crystallographically equivalent uranyl center U1, sharing one equatorial edge with each other through two O atoms with U-O bond lengths of 2.259(3) and 2.361(3) Å (Table S1). Besides, two N atoms from a phen molecule and an end η1-carboxyl O atom (O8) of L1  linker occupy the residual coordination sites of the equatorial plane with U-O bond length of 2.347(9) Å, and U-N bond lengths of 2.608(4) and 2.605(4) Å, respectively (c). The other N-donor end of the bridging L1  linker is coordinated with the tetra-nuclear motif (U2-N3, 2.648(3) Å). Besides, another two L1  linkers also coordinate to the tetra-nuclear motif (d) by the carboxyl group in a bidentate bridging mode (U2-O10, 2.433(3) Å; U3-O11, 2.358(3) Å), leaving the other pyridine-containing end uncoordinated and dangled. Moreover, phen molecules chelate to the tetra-nuclear uranyl in a way similar to that in dimeric uranyl (U3-N4, 2.691(4) Å; U3-N5, 2.679(3) Å). It is interesting to find that, all the dangled L1  linkers and phen molecules are orderly aligned as branch motifs on both sides along the 1D chain formed containing dimeric and tetrameric uranyl clusters. These widespread conjugated groups of dangled L1  linkers and phen molecules promote the formation of a 3D supramolecular architecture via π-π interactions (e and Figure S3). Specifically, the π-π interaction arises mainly from the stacking of side-on phen moieties binding to tetra-nuclear uranyl entities with a face-to-face distance (Cg(1)-Cg(2)) of 3.673(0) Å (f and ), which makes different components in 1 to hold together tightly. Certainly, besides π-π interactions, widespread C-H⋅⋅⋅O(axial) or C-H⋅⋅⋅N(prydinyl) also contribute to the crystal lattice stacking in 3D space (Figure S4 and Table S2).

Crystallographic analysis of 2 reveals that it crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅, and a 1D uranyl-organic chain with a main backbone of infinite polynuclear uranyl ribbon consisting of alternative dimeric and tetrameric uranyl subunits is achieved in 2 (Figure S5 and a,b). A further analysis indicates that, except the substitution of bridging L1 linkers by μ2-OH groups for linking the tetra-nuclear and dimeric uranyl units in the main backbone of 1D chain, all the other parts of uranyl center coordination spheres in 2 are nearly identical to those of 1. In other words, there are also three kinds of uranyl centers (U1, U2, and U3) with different coordination environments in 2, although they are all 7-fold coordinated in a pentagonal bipyramid geometry. As c illustrates, the U1 center is featured as a dimeric uranyl motif with two equivalent uranyl units connecting equatorially with one phen group through two N atoms with bond distances of 2.647(4) and 2.604(4) Å. The residual coordinated sites of U1 are occupied by three μ2-OH atoms with U–O distances ranging from 2.260(3) to 2.347(4) Å, two of which are from the sharing edge of dimeric uranyl motif and another of which is with the tetrameric subcomponents containing U2 and U3. It is noticed that the dimeric uranyl unit is not connected with adjacent tetrameric units through the bridging L1 linker any longer, but directly through a shorter bridging μ2-OH (O8) groups. Similarly, for the tetrameric unit in 2, the bridging μ2-OH (O8) group on the equatorial plane of U2 replaces the N-donor of bridging L1 linker as observed in 1, and combines with other μ3-O and μ2-OH groups as well as the dangled L1 linkers and phen molecules to form the final coordination spheres of tetrameric uranyl units (d).

elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of 2: (a) two sets of uranyl polyhedral in 2; (b) the sawtoothed extended 1D chain of 2; (c) coordination sphere of the dimeric uranyl block; (d) coordination sphere of the tetrameric uranyl block. Yellow polyhedrons denote uranyl coordination spheres.

elements.content: Again, similar to 1, all the orderly aligned dangled L1 linkers and phen molecules on both sides along 1D uranyl-organic chains contribute to the crystal packing of 1D chains through extensive hydrogen bonds (Figure S4 and Table S2). However, it should be mentioned that, unlike the nearly straight conformation of 1D chain in 1, the direct connection of tetrameric and dimeric uranyl motifs in 2 by an almost perpendicular pattern with a dihedral angle of 77.36° (Figure S6) leads to a sawtoothed topology of 1D chain (b). This zigzag geometry of 1D chain changes the relative orientation of dangled L1 linkers and the phen molecules on both sides of it and subsequently affect the formation of π–π interactions and the final crystal packing mode of 1D chains. Therefore, the crystal packing of 2 in three-dimensional crystal lattice is a little different from that of 1. For example, the most distinctive feature of π–π interactions in 2 is the involvement of dangled L1 linkers, which is not found in 1. As shown in and Figure S7, there are two kinds of π–π interactions along different directions found in 2 (). The first kind is π–π interactions between two sets of VP moieties of dangled L1 linkers and neighboring phen groups from two adjacent zigzag chains along axis b (a and c). We denote these π–π interactions as phen···VP···VP···phen with the phen···VP distance of 4.103(3) Å (corresponding to Cg(2)-Cg(3) as shown in a and c) and the VP···VP distance of 3.833(4) Å (corresponding to Cg(3)-Cg(3) as shown in a and c). Besides, phen molecules connecting uranyl dimeric blocks from the adjacent chains along axis a are also aligned orderly in distance of 3.889(1) Å (corresponding to Cg(1)-Cg(1) in b and d), forming another set of strong π–π interactions and thus also contribute to the close stacking of 2 (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: Again, similar to 1, all the orderly aligned dangled L1  linkers and phen molecules on both sides along 1D uranyl-organic chains contribute to the crystal packing of 1D chains through extensive hydrogen bonds (Figure S4 and Table S2). However, it should be mentioned that, unlike the nearly straight conformation of 1D chain in 1, the direct connection of tetrameric and dimeric uranyl motifs in 2 by an almost perpendicular pattern with a dihedral angle of 77.36° (Figure S6) leads to a sawtoothed topology of 1D chain (b). This zigzag geometry of 1D chain changes the relative orientation of dangled L1  linkers and the phen molecules on both sides of it and subsequently affect the formation of π-π interactions and the final crystal packing mode of 1D chains. Therefore, the crystal packing of 2 in three-dimensional crystal lattice is a little different from that of 1. For example, the most distinctive feature of π-π interactions in 2 is the involvement of dangled L1  linkers, which is not found in 1. As shown in  and Figure S7, there are two kinds of π-π interactions along different directions found in 2 (). The first kind is π-π interactions between two sets of VP moieties of dangled L1  linkers and neighboring phen groups from two adjacent zigzag chains along axis b (a and c). We denote these π-π interactions as phen⋅⋅⋅VP⋅⋅⋅VP⋅⋅⋅phen with the phen⋅⋅⋅VP distance of 4.103(3) Å (corresponding to Cg(2)-Cg(3) as shown in a and c) and the VP⋅⋅⋅VP distance of 3.833(4) Å (corresponding to Cg(3)-Cg(3) as shown in a and c). Besides, phen molecules connecting uranyl dimeric blocks from the adjacent chains along axis a are also aligned orderly in distance of 3.889(1) Å (corresponding to Cg(1)-Cg(1) in b and d), forming another set of strong π-π interactions and thus also contribute to the close stacking of 2 (Figure S7).

elements.content: When starting from L2 -OMe, a 3-vinylpyridinyl-containing positional isomer of L1 -OMe, compound 3 was produced. Crystallographic analysis reveals that the molecular composition and chemical structure of 3 are totally identical to those of 2 ( and S8), the only difference between them being the isomeric carboxylate ligands L2 and L1 . Similar to their precursors of L2 -OMe and L1 -OMe, 3 and 2 are also positional isomers. Therefore, the specific bond parameters in 3, such as bond lengths, bond angles, and the distances of hydrogen bonds (Figure S4 and Table S2) and π–π stacking () also only show a few changes compared with these of 2. Specifically, U1 in the structural unit of 3 is bound to two N atoms from phen and three μ2-OH atoms in the equatorial plane, with equatorial U–O bond lengths ranging from 2.257(8) to 2.354(8) Å, and U–N bond lengths of 2.617(9) and 2.646(10) Å. For another two uranyl centers in the tetrameric unit, U2 is coordinated with three μ2-OH and two μ3-O atoms in its equatorial plane with a distance from 2.259(7) to 2.489(8) Å, and the equatorial coordination sphere of U3 is completed by two N atoms with distances of 2.693(9) and 2.689(10) Å, and three O atoms with distances ranging from 2.235(7) to 2.365(10) Å. Moreover, the twist angle between tetrameric and dimeric uranyl units is 79.88° for 3, which is just 2.52° larger than that found in 2 (Figure S6). The axial UO distances are in the range of 1.755(10) and 1.802(7) Å, and the UO bond angles are from 173.3(4)° to 177.2(0)°. Similar to 2, there are also abundant π–π interactions among conjugated phen groups and L2 linkers with modest contact distances of 3.875(7) Å (Cg(1)–Cg(1)), 3.955(4) Å (Cg(2)–Cg(3)) and 3.844(0) Å (Cg(3)–Cg(3)) ( and ).

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P1̅, and contains a single uranyl center in its asymmetric unit (Figure S9) as the nonequivalent part of a dimeric uranyl motif bridged by two μ2-OH atoms (a). The coordination sphere of each uranyl center is further completed by a η1 -mode carboxylate group from a L2 linker and two N atoms from a bidentate phen group with a U–O distance of 2.334(6) Å and U–N bond lengths of 2.624(5) and 2.606(5) Å. The bond angle between the two axial UO bonds (U1–O1 and U1–O2) is 176.2(6)° with bond lengths of 1.767(7) and 1.778(6) Å, respectively. Interestingly, a detailed comparison of 4 with the previously mentioned dimeric uranyl units reveals that the molecular structure of 4, although it does not extend by the coordination of pyridine group to form an infinite chain, is nearly identical to the dimeric uranyl motif in 1. Obviously, high similarity in partial components but difference in whole structure contributes to the subtle structural change from L1 to L2 and subsequent distinction of coordination behaviors and/or crystal packing. Finally, we also note the presence of π–π interactions between all the adjacent dimers (b), with a ring centroid–centroid distance (corresponding to Cg(1)–Cg(2)) of 3.670(7) Å for L2 and phen motifs nearly arranged in parallel (c and d and ), which facilitates the crystal stacking of 4 in three-dimensional space (Figure S10). Besides, widespread C–H···O (axial) hydrogen bonds are also found in the crystal lattice of 4 (Figure S4 and Table S2).

elements.content: When a competing metal source, ZnSO4, was introduced in the hydrothermal system of uranyl and L2 -OMe, only a heterometallic uranyl complex 5 was produced. The structure of 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P1̅ with both a monomeric uranyl unit and a zinc center (a and S11). The uranyl center is 7-fold coordinated with a pentagonal bipyramid geometry, and all five coordination sites in the equatorial plane are occupied by O atoms (two from sulfate ions, two from μ2-OH groups, and one from water molecule) with U–O distances ranging from 2.303(6) to 2.549(1) Å (b). The zinc center is coordinated by two N atoms from phen with Zn–N bond lengths of 2.138(8) and 2.112(9) Å, as well as three O atoms shared with three adjacent uranyl centers (two μ2-OH groups and one axial O atom) with Zn–O bond lengths from 1.956(7) to 2.496(7) Å (b). These uranyl and zinc centers connecting to each other through bridging O atoms extend to form a 1D chain, which further assemblies into a 3D supramolecular uranyl-organic framework (c). It is noteworthy that UO–Zn connection, which is usually named as cation–cation interactions (CCIs), plays a vital role in the formation of 1D chain. This special connection makes all the phen moieties in the 1D chain aligned on both sides (d). Ultimately, the whole structure of 5 in crystal lattice is held by strong π–π stacking (d and e) and hydrogen bonds (Figure S4 and Table S2). It can be seen that the ordered arrangement of phen enables it to interact with its neighboring chains by π–π interaction with a distance of 3.514(8) Å (Cg(1)–Cg(1)) (e).

elements.content: The PXRD spectra were recorded for compounds 1, 3, and 5 (2 and 4 in pure phase could not be isolated in sufficient yields). The PXRD patterns of all three compounds (Figures S12–14) are in good accordance with the simulated pattern, which indicates their high phase purity and ensures the utility of them in the following studies. TGA analyses of 1, 3, and 5 (Figure S15–16) show that the weight loss of them initiates at 165, 226, and 218 °C, respectively, which correspond to thermally induced loss of water. The main backbone decomposition of 1 occurs when the temperature goes up to ∼282 °C, while that of 3 undergoes a sharp weight decrease starting from ∼299 °C. This result demonstrates that 3 has a better thermal stability compared with that of 1, which can be attributed to its infinite uranyl chain in 3 instead of isolated tetrameric and dimeric uranyl units in 1. Compound 5 with the most compact structure has the best thermal stability with a decomposition temperature of ∼431 °C, and achieves complete thermal decomposition at ∼565 °C. The IR spectra of 1, 3, and 5 as well as 2 as a comparison (Figure S17) give typical UO stretching vibration peaks in the range of 875–904 cm–1. The slight difference among them can be attributed to different coordination sphere variation of uranyl. The IR spectra peaks at the region of 1388 to 1635 cm–1 manifest the existence of carboxylate groups. Besides, the ν­(C–H)­vibration of pyridinyl groups is obviously observed at ∼839 cm–1 and the vibration peaks of phenyl are in the range of 717–725 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD), Infrared Spectroscopy (IR), Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA), and Fluorescence Properties

The PXRD spectra were recorded for compounds 1, 3, and 5 (2 and 4 in pure phase could not be isolated in sufficient yields). The PXRD patterns of all three compounds (Figures S12-14) are in good accordance with the simulated pattern, which indicates their high phase purity and ensures the utility of them in the following studies. TGA analyses of 1, 3, and 5 (Figure S15-16) show that the weight loss of them initiates at 165, 226, and 218 °C, respectively, which correspond to thermally induced loss of water. The main backbone decomposition of 1 occurs when the temperature goes up to ~282 °C, while that of 3 undergoes a sharp weight decrease starting from ~299 °C. This result demonstrates that 3 has a better thermal stability compared with that of 1, which can be attributed to its infinite uranyl chain in 3 instead of isolated tetrameric and dimeric uranyl units in 1. Compound 5 with the most compact structure has the best thermal stability with a decomposition temperature of ~431 °C, and achieves complete thermal decomposition at ~565 °C. The IR spectra of 1, 3, and 5 as well as 2 as a comparison (Figure S17) give typical UO stretching vibration peaks in the range of 875-904 cm-1. The slight difference among them can be attributed to different coordination sphere variation of uranyl. The IR spectra peaks at the region of 1388 to 1635 cm-1 manifest the existence of carboxylate groups. Besides, the ν(C-H)vibration of pyridinyl groups is obviously observed at ~839 cm-1 and the vibration peaks of phenyl are in the range of 717-725 cm-1.

elements.content: Fluorescence spectra of 1, 3, and 5 were recorded under excitation at a wavelength of 420 nm (). Compound 5 shows the typical vibronic progression of uranium­(VI) with the five main emission bands located in the range of 502–631 nm, corresponding to the S11 → S00 and S10 → S0ν (ν = 0–4) electronic transitions. Compared with 5, a red shift has been observed for the weak vibronic peaks of 1 and 3, which might be related to different coordination groups of the uranyl centers in these two compounds. Moreover, it is obviously to find that the emission peaks in the luminescence spectra of 1 and 3 is widened, which could be attributed to the polynuclear form of uranyl, and the slight difference of peak shapes between them is caused by their different connection type, that the uranyl center in 1 is two isolated dimeric and tetra-nuclear forms linked by a double-ended L2 linker, while that in 3 is a 1D uranyl chain with alternate dimeric and tetrametric units connected directly by a bridging hydroxyl group.

elements.content: As demonstrated above, the synthesis of uranyl compounds based on VP-contained monocarboxylate linker L1 or L2 is largely dependent on synthesis precursors and experimental conditions, and there are several factors controlling the synthesis process and lead to structural diversity of final products ().
elements.clean_text:
Factors Controlling the Synthesis and Structural Diversity

As demonstrated above, the synthesis of uranyl compounds based on VP-contained monocarboxylate linker L1  or L2  is largely dependent on synthesis precursors and experimental conditions, and there are several factors controlling the synthesis process and lead to structural diversity of final products ().

elements.content: Structural diversity of uranyl compounds 1–5 based on L1 or L2 .
elements.clean_text: 9  Structural diversity of uranyl compounds 1-5 based on L1  or L2 .

elements.content: The factor at the first place should be the pH of the reaction solution. It directly affects the hydrolysis of carboxylate ester and deprotonation of carboxylic groups, which is important to their coordination with uranyl center. Meanwhile, the speciation of uranyl under hydrothermal conditions is closely related with the solution pH values. For instance, the occurrence of possible dimeric and tetrameric uranyl species in 1–4 should have originated from relatively high pH after adding a considerable amount of NaOH solution. Moreover, the structural variance for the same ligand system (such as 3 and 4 based on L2 and phen ligands) seems to be attributed to the difference of pH as well since more NaOH added might induce higher degree of uranyl hydrolysis and higher-nuclear uranyl oligomers.
elements.clean_text: The factor at the first place should be the pH of the reaction solution. It directly affects the hydrolysis of carboxylate ester and deprotonation of carboxylic groups, which is important to their coordination with uranyl center. Meanwhile, the speciation of uranyl under hydrothermal conditions is closely related with the solution pH values. For instance, the occurrence of possible dimeric and tetrameric uranyl species in 1-4 should have originated from relatively high pH after adding a considerable amount of NaOH solution. Moreover, the structural variance for the same ligand system (such as 3 and 4 based on L2  and phen ligands) seems to be attributed to the difference of pH as well since more NaOH added might induce higher degree of uranyl hydrolysis and higher-nuclear uranyl oligomers.

elements.content: Other factors affecting the synthesis should be organic ligands as well as different additives such as phen as an auxiliary ligand or ZnSO4 as a competing agent. As an organic base with good metal coordination ability, phen acts in different roles including coligands, charge compensators, templating agents, or space filling molecules when used for the construction of uranyl hybrids. In our work here, initial efforts to produce uranyl compounds of L1 or L2 in the absence of phen turned out to be a failure, indicating that phen is very important in the formation of uranyl-organic compounds based on VP-containing L1 or L2 . Given the feature of monocarboxylate and high molecular rigidity for L1 or L2 , phen indeed can serve in both roles as a coligand and a structure-directing agent via its good chelating capacity with metal center by two space-adjacent N-donors and strong tendency to achieve π-conjugated stacking. On the other hand, it is not all the additives that play a positive role for the formation of uranyl compounds of L1 or L2 as exemplified by the case of 5 obtained in the presence of ZnSO4. As previous reports show, the involvement of 3d or 4f metal ions can bring new uranyl-heterometallic coordination compounds with higher-dimensional frameworks, since d-block metal ions commonly with polyhedral coordination geometries can increase the structural connectivity through their cross-linking abilities. What we initially aimed at by introducing ZnSO4 is to increase the dimensionality of the final uranyl compound via possible coordination between noncoordinated N atoms of dangled L1 or L2 and the N-preferred Zn ions. Unfortunately, although a new uranyl-zinc heterometallic compound comprised mainly of four different components (uranyl, zinc, phen, and sulfate) was obtained, the addition of ZnSO4 does not work as expected because the final product, that is 5, excludes the L2 linker from the coordination spheres of uranyl or zinc, or may not be in the crystal lattice of the final main product 5. It might be, according to the hard–soft acid–base theory (HSAB), attributed to the N-donor phen preference to Zn­(II) ion rather than uranyl ion, and uranyl will be deprived of coordination ability with phen after the addition of Zn­(II). Meanwhile, the added sulfate ion with four O-donor atoms competes with L2 to coordinate with uranyl, thus leaving L2 to be forced out of the coordination sphere of uranyl.

elements.content: It is found that there is also some difference between uranyl compounds from L1 and L2 , e.g., 1 and 4, which indicates that minor changes of organic ligands used here, i.e., change of the location of pyridinyl nitrogen atom from from 4- (or para-) in L1 to 3- (or meta-) in L2 , also have much influence on their coordination and assembly behavior. Although dimeric uranyl can be found in both compounds as a subcomponent of 1D chain or an isolated unit, the coordination modes of pyridinyl at the N-donor end of L1 or L2 for 1 and 4 are totally different. The pyridinyl at the N-donor end of L1 in 1 is further coordinated to tetrameric uranyl unit and finally results in a 1D uranyl-organic chain, which extends along the diagonal direction through π–π interaction to form the final 3D structure, while that of L2 in 4 is just noncoordinated. The difference in structures of 1 and 4 may be attributed to a combined electronic and steric effect. In terms of electronic effect, the vinyl moiety as an electron-releasing group (ERG) might effectively increase charge density of the N-donor at its para-position than that at the meta-position, and thus endows N-donor with better coordination ability to uranyl centers. The other cause for the difference of 1 and 4 could be steric effect. It is reasonable to speculate that the N-donor at its para-position of L1 bears better geometrical symmetry, which is crucial to the extension of the 1D chain as well as crystal packing in the three-dimensional lattice. As a result, these unfavorable factors result in the noncoordinated feature of N-donor pyridinyl of L2 in 4.
elements.clean_text: It is found that there is also some difference between uranyl compounds from L1  and L2 , e.g., 1 and 4, which indicates that minor changes of organic ligands used here, i.e., change of the location of pyridinyl nitrogen atom from from 4- (or para-) in L1  to 3- (or meta-) in L2 , also have much influence on their coordination and assembly behavior. Although dimeric uranyl can be found in both compounds as a subcomponent of 1D chain or an isolated unit, the coordination modes of pyridinyl at the N-donor end of L1  or L2  for 1 and 4 are totally different. The pyridinyl at the N-donor end of L1  in 1 is further coordinated to tetrameric uranyl unit and finally results in a 1D uranyl-organic chain, which extends along the diagonal direction through π-π interaction to form the final 3D structure, while that of L2  in 4 is just noncoordinated. The difference in structures of 1 and 4 may be attributed to a combined electronic and steric effect. In terms of electronic effect, the vinyl moiety as an electron-releasing group (ERG) might effectively increase charge density of the N-donor at its para-position than that at the meta-position, and thus endows N-donor with better coordination ability to uranyl centers. The other cause for the difference of 1 and 4 could be steric effect. It is reasonable to speculate that the N-donor at its para-position of L1  bears better geometrical symmetry, which is crucial to the extension of the 1D chain as well as crystal packing in the three-dimensional lattice. As a result, these unfavorable factors result in the noncoordinated feature of N-donor pyridinyl of L2  in 4.

elements.content: As uranyl-organic coordination compounds having photoactive vinylpyridine motifs (except 5), 1 and 3 are selected as model compounds for exploring their photoresponsive behaviors here. Crystals of both of 1 and 3 were irradiated for 1, 4, 7 h under 365 nm UV lamp (100 W), and the process is monitored through fluorescence spectra. As shown in and , it is interesting to find that the emission intensity of these two compounds decreases gradually over the exposure time of irradiation. The light-induced fluorescence attenuation for 1 and 3 proves them to be photoresponsive as expected and should be attributed to their light-induced structural change. To investigate the possible change occurring in 1 and 3 after UV-irradiation, PXRD of 1-ir and 3-ir was first determined, which surprisingly displayed nearly identical patterns before and after irradiation (Figures S19, 20). Considering the unchanged PXRD patterns, a possible explanation for light-induced fluorescence attenuation is a mechanism raised by Wang: after the exposure to radiation, the carbonyl double bonds break to generate oxo-radicals that can lead to effective photoluminescence quenching through phonon-assisted relaxation and be easily recovered by heating. To prove this hypothesis, we heated samples of 1-ir and 3-ir at 180 °C for 12 h to check if the recovery of fluorescence is reversible. However, fluorescence of 1-ir and 3-ir cannot be recovered to the initial states ( and ), though the PXRD patterns of samples (namely as 1-ir-heat and 3-ir-heat) after the heating process are still the same as those without irradiation and/or heating (Figure S18 and S19). Therefore, the mechanism of oxo-radicals should not contribute to the light-induced fluorescence attenuation found here.

Light-Induced Fluorescence Attenuation

As uranyl-organic coordination compounds having photoactive vinylpyridine motifs (except 5), 1 and 3 are selected as model compounds for exploring their photoresponsive behaviors here. Crystals of both of 1 and 3 were irradiated for 1, 4, 7 h under 365 nm UV lamp (100 W), and the process is monitored through fluorescence spectra. As shown in  and , it is interesting to find that the emission intensity of these two compounds decreases gradually over the exposure time of irradiation. The light-induced fluorescence attenuation for 1 and 3 proves them to be photoresponsive as expected and should be attributed to their light-induced structural change. To investigate the possible change occurring in 1 and 3 after UV-irradiation, PXRD of 1-ir and 3-ir was first determined, which surprisingly displayed nearly identical patterns before and after irradiation (Figures S19, 20). Considering the unchanged PXRD patterns, a possible explanation for light-induced fluorescence attenuation is a mechanism raised by Wang: after the exposure to radiation, the carbonyl double bonds break to generate oxo-radicals that can lead to effective photoluminescence quenching through phonon-assisted relaxation and be easily recovered by heating. To prove this hypothesis, we heated samples of 1-ir and 3-ir at 180 °C for 12 h to check if the recovery of fluorescence is reversible. However, fluorescence of 1-ir and 3-ir cannot be recovered to the initial states ( and ), though the PXRD patterns of samples (namely as 1-ir-heat and 3-ir-heat) after the heating process are still the same as those without irradiation and/or heating (Figure S18 and S19). Therefore, the mechanism of oxo-radicals should not contribute to the light-induced fluorescence attenuation found here.

elements.content: Fortunately, crystal samples of 1 and 3 after irradiation and/or heating are still suitable for X-ray single crystal structural determination, and thus enable us to access to the precise structural information after UV-irradiation and recognize the possible mechanism for light-induced fluorescence attenuation. Crystal structure data of 1-ir and 3-ir reveals that the main structures of these two compounds after UV irradiation is retained with similar cell parameters and molecular structures to their intact precursors (Table S3), which is in accordance with their high similarity in PXRD patterns. Meanwhile, the unchanged structure after UV irradiation also excludes the possibility of fluorescence attenuation through complex oxidation or decomposition. Detailed analysis shows that, although the skeletons of uranyl-organic compounds in 1-ir and 1-ir-heat or 3-ir and 3-ir-heat do not change, the local structures in their crystal lattice, especially those of VP and phen groups which are held together by weak interactions such as π–π interactions and hydrogen bonds, display some differences compared with their precursors ( and ).

Considering the vital role of photoactive VP moiety in light-induced fluorescence attenuation, we focus mainly on the changes of bond parameters of VP-related groups, which refer to hydrogen bonds involving O1, O9, and N6 for 1, and both hydrogen bonds involving O2, O6, and N5 as well as π–π interactions involving Cg(2) and Cg(3) in 3 (). It is surprising that, in terms of parameters of weak interactions, the changes between 1, 1-ir, and 1-ir-heat or between 3, 3-ir, and 3-ir-heat are evident. For example, hydrogen bond of [C21–H21···O1] in 1 is elongated from 2.525(5) to 2.579(1) Å with a [D–H···A] angle changing from 136.6(3)° to 138.3(13)° after UV-irradiation, and does not recover through a follow-up heating process (distance of H···A: 2.555(4) Å, [D–H···A] angle: 137.7(4)°). A similar trend is observed for 3, which undergoes a structural change of [C31–H31···O6] from 2.787(9) to 2.960(1) Å) with a [D–H···A] angle changing from 137.2(9)° to 142.2(14)° (). The most striking is changes of dihedral angles between two aromatic rings with π–π interactions (Cg(2)···Cg(3) changing from 3.838(1)° to 2.715(2)° and Cg(3)···Cg(3) from 0° to 3.565(7)°) (), which reveals that the pyridinyl group should take a rotary process during the irradiation. As previous literature reported, photoactive double bonds can undergo a photodimerization or a cis–trans isomerization together with rotational motions after UV irradiation. Although neither a photodimerization nor a cis–trans isomerization process has occurred after irradiation here, the double bond of VP might experience a slight rotational motion. In other words, VP motif absorbs energy from UV irradiation, activates the carbon–carbon double bond, and enables pyridinyl group to slightly rotate around it.

elements.content: Another question is why the irradiated samples, 1-ir and 3-ir (also for 1-ir-heat and 3-ir-heat) with a slight rotation of pyridinyl group, undergo fluorescence attenuation. The cause for this is certainly related with the minor change of VP. Inspired by the mechanism of restriction of intramolecular rotations (RIR) for aggregation-induced emission (AIE) phenomena (a), a reasonable explanation is that the light-induced rotation of pyridinyl group will lead to possible disturbance to orderly crystal stacking, and subsequently enable increasing freedom of VP(b), which finally results in the increased degree of nonradiative relaxation of excited states and fluorescence attenuation of 1-ir and 3-ir.

elements.content: In summary, five uranyl coordination compounds were synthesized from hydrothermal reaction of photoactive vinyl group-contained ligand L1 -OMe or L2 -OMe, and 1,10-phenanthroline with uranyl nitrate. All compounds are abundant in π–π interactions, and show structural diversity. Furthermore, both compounds 1 and 3, which are selected as representative samples to conduct the light-induced experiments, show fluorescence attenuation after UV irradiation. As suggested by single crystal structural analysis, the mechanism may be explained by a slight rotation of pyridinyl group around the carbon–carbon double bond, causing the stacking to be disordered to some degree, and finally increased the degree of nonradiative relaxation of excited states. All these results indicate that the introduction of the photoactive vinyl group could be an effective approach to regulate the fluorescence of uranyl-organic coordination compounds with structural diversity and unique properties obtained here, and should provide some hints to new strategies for the functionalization of the actinide-bearing materials, and offer opportunities to extend their potent application to the field of photoresponsive sensor materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, five uranyl coordination compounds were synthesized from hydrothermal reaction of photoactive vinyl group-contained ligand L1 -OMe or L2 -OMe, and 1,10-phenanthroline with uranyl nitrate. All compounds are abundant in π-π interactions, and show structural diversity. Furthermore, both compounds 1 and 3, which are selected as representative samples to conduct the light-induced experiments, show fluorescence attenuation after UV irradiation. As suggested by single crystal structural analysis, the mechanism may be explained by a slight rotation of pyridinyl group around the carbon-carbon double bond, causing the stacking to be disordered to some degree, and finally increased the degree of nonradiative relaxation of excited states. All these results indicate that the introduction of the photoactive vinyl group could be an effective approach to regulate the fluorescence of uranyl-organic coordination compounds with structural diversity and unique properties obtained here, and should provide some hints to new strategies for the functionalization of the actinide-bearing materials, and offer opportunities to extend their potent application to the field of photoresponsive sensor materials.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 100 μL), L1 -OMe (16.3 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (18.1 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (1 M, 120 μL), and ultrapure water (2.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL stainless steel bomb. The bomb was sealed, heated to 150 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. Bright-yellow prismatic crystals of 1, accompanied by a small amount of yellow floc, were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ethanol and ultrapure water, and subjected to air drying at room temperature. Yield: 6.4 mg, 10.7% based on uranium. Elemental analysis calculated for C40H28N6O13U3, C, 31.67; H, 1.99; N, 5.54. Found: C, 33.80; H, 2.24; N, 5.81% (the deviation beyond the ±0.4% range is mainly originated from a small amount of impurity including reactants and/or byproducts generating during the hydrothermal reaction between multiple components; according to the experimental analysis result, the sample purity for compound 1 is still as high as ∼98%, which is also evidenced by the high similarity of PXRD patterns between experimental data and simulated data as shown in SI).

(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-O)­(μ<sub>2</sub>-OH)<sub>3</sub>(<bold>L<sub>1</sub> </bold>)­(phen)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (0.50 M, 100 μL), L1 -OMe­(16.3 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,10-phenanthroline (18.1 mg, 0.10 mmol), NaOH (1 M, 100 μL), and ultrapure water (2.0 mL) were loaded into a 15 mL stainless steel bomb. The bomb was sealed, heated to 150 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to ambient temperature. Bright-yellow sheet crystals of 2, accompanied by a significant amount of yellow floc, were produced; the yellow crystals were filtered off, rinsed with ethanol and ultrapure water, and subjected to air drying at room temperature.

(E)-3-(Pyridin-4-yl)­acrylic acid (HL1 ) and (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-4-yl)­acrylate (L1 -OMe), (E)-3-(pyridin-3-yl)­acrylic acid (HL2 ), and (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-4-yl)­acrylate (L2 -OMe), and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Photoactive VP-Functionalized Organic Ligands Used in This Work      a (E)-3-(Pyridin-4-yl)acrylic acid (HL1 ) and (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-4-yl)acrylate (L1 -OMe), (E)-3-(pyridin-3-yl)acrylic acid (HL2 ), and (E)-methyl 3-(pyridin-4-yl)acrylate (L2 -OMe), and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen).

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 1: (a) Two sets of uranyl polyhedral in 1, dimeric and tetrameric uranyl units; (b) the extended 1D chain of 1, showing the connection of the dinuclear blocks with the tetranuclear blocks through bridging L1 linkers; (c) coordination sphere of the dinuclear uranyl block; (d) coordination sphere of the tetra-nuclear uranyl block; (e) 3D stacking structure of 1 through π–π interactions viewed from axis a; (f) the face-to-face distance of π–π stacking between two adjacent phen motifs in 1. Color codes: yellow polyhedrons denote uranyl coordination spheres, orange sticks denote covalent or coordination bonds and brown polygons are phen aromatic rings.

cln_elements.content: (a) Mechanism of restriction of intramolecular rotations (RIR) for aggregation-induced emission (AIE) phenomena.
